body_html:
As of April 2018, and to save a lot of googling and investigating, TF 1.7 and 1.8 are not compatible with CUDA 9.1. So you have to use 9.0 unfort.
Furthermore, you have to use cuDNN 7.0 NOT 7.1 (at least on a Windows 10 machine)
Don't make the mistake of installing cuDNN 7.1, as that is not yet supported.

If you've installed cuDNN 7.1, found it not to be compatible, and downloaded cuDNN 7.0, the CUDA 9.0 probably still has the old cuDNN 7.1 files installed in your CUDA\v9.0 folder. There are 3 files in particular you must copy from your cuDNN 7.0 folder into the CUDA\v9.0 folder to replace the incorrect cuDNN 7.1 versions. cudnn64_7.dll, cudnn.h, & cudnn.lib

This is detailed in nVidia's pdf here (pages 6-7): https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/sdk/pdf/cuDNN-Installation-Guide.pdf

After that, follow the next step to set the CUDA_PATH environment variable.
Click OK, close, restart your machine, and should be good to go.

Downgrading those 3 files from the cuDNN 7.1 back to the 7.0 was what solved the issue for me.

If you've installed cuDNN 7.1, found it not to be compatible, and downloaded cuDNN 7.0, the CUDA 9.0 probably still has the old cuDNN 7.1 files installed in your CUDA\v9.0 folder.  There are 3 files in particular you must copy from your cuDNN 7.0 folder into the CUDA\v9.0 folder to replace the incorrect cuDNN 7.1 versions. cudnn64_7.dll, cudnn.h, & cudnn.lib
This is detailed in nVidia's pdf here (pages 6-7):  https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/sdk/pdf/cuDNN-Installation-Guide.pdf
After that, follow the next step to set the CUDA_PATH environment variable.

body:
As of April 2018, and to save a lot of googling and investigating, TF 1.7 and 1.8 are not compatible with CUDA 9.1.  So you have to use 9.0 unfort.
Furthermore, you have to use cuDNN 7.0 NOT 7.1 (at least on a Windows 10 machine)
Don't make the mistake of installing cuDNN 7.1, as that is not yet supported.

If you've installed cuDNN 7.1, found it not to be compatible, and downloaded cuDNN 7.0, the CUDA 9.0 probably still has the old cuDNN 7.1 files installed in your CUDA\v9.0 folder.  There are 3 files in particular you must copy from your cuDNN 7.0 folder into the CUDA\v9.0 folder to replace the incorrect cuDNN 7.1 versions. cudnn64_7.dll, cudnn.h, & cudnn.lib

This is detailed in nVidia's pdf here (pages 6-7):  https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/sdk/pdf/cuDNN-Installation-Guide.pdf

After that, follow the next step to set the CUDA_PATH environment variable.
Click OK, close, restart your machine, and should be good to go.

Downgrading those 3 files from the cuDNN 7.1 back to the 7.0 was what solved the issue for me.
